<h1><a name="_Toc485150867"><span lang=EN-GB style='color:#92D050;mso-ansi-language:
EN-GB'>Chapter 1: Before you start</span></a><span lang=EN-GB style='color:
#92D050;mso-ansi-language:EN-GB'><o:p></o:p></span></h1>

<h2><a name="_Toc485150868"><span lang=EN-GB style='color:#92D050;mso-ansi-language:
EN-GB'>Is openHAB2 the right choice for my home automation project?</span></a><span
lang=EN-GB style='color:#92D050;mso-ansi-language:EN-GB'><o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-GB style='color:#92D050;mso-ansi-language:
EN-GB'>Be aware that openHAB2 is an OPEN home automation solution which is
strongly living from a very supportive community. If you want to have a plug
and play solution with supplier guaranteed service level and a high likeliness
that all the features are working and all the hardware is compatible, you might
be better off in getting a ready to use home automation kit including the
designated controller (like e.g. devolo or homematic IP). Consider this
especially if you are planning to do safety related automation or emergency
detection like fire alarm. <o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-GB style='color:#92D050;mso-ansi-language:
EN-GB'>If you, on the other hand, are willing to spend a few hrs/days in
learning how to do a little installation and coding yourself and have no
problems with the service level of a Raspberry Pi 3 (it is not as failsafe as
other controllers) you might find a perfect environment with openHAB2 for your
low cost, very flexible and continuously improving home automation environment.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<h2><a name="_Toc485150869"><span lang=EN-GB style='color:#92D050;mso-ansi-language:
EN-GB'>Introduction:</span></a><span lang=EN-GB style='color:#92D050;
mso-ansi-language:EN-GB'><o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-GB style='color:#92D050;mso-ansi-language:
EN-GB'>This tutorial is targeting beginners like me to get a step by step
guideline to get all the things installed. Since I am no coding expert and have
no experience in Raspberry and Raspbian I am trying to go through the things
step by step, so you should be able to get everything done, even without
exactly having to go into all the details. That is one of the reasons I am also
using the graphical GUI PIXEL for Raspbian since I thing it makes it easier for
the beginners to get started (and you might want to use PIXEL anyway when you
are using the Raspberry 7 display as interface for your home automation
controller)<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-GB style='color:#92D050;mso-ansi-language:
EN-GB'>This tutorial is also based on <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>having
a Windows PC</b> to support the setup process. You might be able to completely
do it without the support of an extra PC, if you can get a MicroSD card with a
pre-installed Raspbian OS and use the display options (the Raspberry 7 display
or HDMI Display) for the Raspberry.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span lang=EN-GB
style='color:#92D050;mso-ansi-language:EN-GB'>DISCLAIMER:<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><i style='mso-bidi-font-style:
normal'><span lang=EN-GB style='color:#92D050;mso-ansi-language:EN-GB'>This
tutorial might contain some typos, errors or ways of setting up, which can be
done in a better way. I am just reflecting my process of starting from scratch
and slowly working my way through hundreds of online tutorials, manuals, forum
threads etc. and on the way, highlighting the issues I had in getting things
working. There will be no guarantee that the given instructions are working for
your project as well.<o:p></o:p></span></i></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-GB style='color:#92D050;mso-ansi-language:
EN-GB'>Anyway I hope this tutorial will help some beginners to enjoy home
automation with openHAB2.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-GB style='color:#92D050;mso-ansi-language:
EN-GB'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></p>

<h2><a name="_Toc485150870"><span lang=EN-GB style='color:#92D050;mso-ansi-language:
EN-GB'>A few words about the 2 in openHAB2:</span></a><span lang=EN-GB
style='color:#92D050;mso-ansi-language:EN-GB'><o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-GB style='color:#92D050;mso-ansi-language:
EN-GB'>The 2 in openHAB2 is important! The tutorial is based on the openHAB2
and will not go into all the details of the old version.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-GB style='color:#92D050;mso-ansi-language:
EN-GB'>You just have to be aware, that a lot of online documentation is still
for the openHAB version and will <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>not</b>
be applicable for openHAB2!<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-GB style='color:#92D050;mso-ansi-language:
EN-GB'>So the best thing is always to go to the official webpage of openHAB2
and start from there, and only if you really cant find the information or the
link there, go to google and search for other solutions. I was always using the
search setting (last year) so it was more likely to the results considering
openHAB2 and not openHAB.<br clear=all style='mso-special-character:line-break;
page-break-before:always'>
<o:p></o:p></span></p>

  <p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0cm;margin-bottom:.0001pt;line-height:
  normal'><span lang=EN-US style='color:#92D050;mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>cd<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0cm;margin-bottom:.0001pt;line-height:
  normal'><span lang=EN-US style='color:#92D050;mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0cm;margin-bottom:.0001pt;line-height:
  normal'><span lang=EN-US style='color:#92D050;mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>cd<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0cm;margin-bottom:.0001pt;line-height:
  normal'><span lang=EN-US style='color:#92D050;mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>cd ..<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0cm;margin-bottom:.0001pt;line-height:
  normal'><span lang=EN-US style='color:#92D050;mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>cd <i

  <p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0cm;margin-bottom:.0001pt;line-height:
  normal'><i style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'><span lang=EN-US
  style='color:#92D050;mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></i></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0cm;margin-bottom:.0001pt;line-height:
  normal'><i style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'><span lang=EN-US
  style='color:#92D050;mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>cd /directory/directory</span></i><span
  lang=EN-US style='color:#92D050;mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p></o:p></span></p>
  </td>
  <td width=377 valign=top style='width:338.45pt;border-top:none;border-left:
  none;border-bottom:solid windowtext 1.0pt;border-right:solid windowtext 1.0pt;
  mso-border-top-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;mso-border-left-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;
  mso-border-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0cm;margin-bottom:.0001pt;line-height:
  normal'><span lang=EN-GB style='color:#92D050;mso-ansi-language:EN-GB'>Is
  changing the shell working directory.<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0cm;margin-bottom:.0001pt;line-height:
  normal'><span lang=EN-GB style='color:#92D050;mso-ansi-language:EN-GB'>It can
  be used with attributes:<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0cm;margin-bottom:.0001pt;line-height:
  normal'><span lang=EN-GB style='color:#92D050;mso-ansi-language:EN-GB'>No
  attribute =&gt; working directory is changed to user root directory.<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0cm;margin-bottom:.0001pt;line-height:
  normal'><span lang=EN-GB style='color:#92D050;mso-ansi-language:EN-GB'>working
  directory is changed to directory one level above<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0cm;margin-bottom:.0001pt;line-height:
  normal'><span lang=EN-GB style='color:#92D050;mso-ansi-language:EN-GB'>working
  directory is changed to the named </span><i style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'><span
  lang=EN-US style='color:#92D050;mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>directory</span></i><span
  lang=EN-GB style='color:#92D050;mso-ansi-language:EN-GB'> inside the current
  directory<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0cm;margin-bottom:.0001pt;line-height:
  normal'><span lang=EN-GB style='color:#92D050;mso-ansi-language:EN-GB'>working
  directory is changed to the directory defined by the full path </span><i
  style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'><span lang=EN-US style='color:#92D050;
  mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>/directory/directory</span></i><span lang=EN-GB
  style='color:#92D050;mso-ansi-language:EN-GB'><o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0cm;margin-bottom:.0001pt;line-height:
  normal'><span lang=EN-GB style='color:#92D050;mso-ansi-language:EN-GB'>.<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr style='mso-yfti-irow:4'>

  <p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0cm;margin-bottom:.0001pt;line-height:

  style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'>filename<o:p></o:p></i></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0cm;margin-bottom:.0001pt;line-height:
  normal'><span lang=EN-US style='color:#92D050;mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>(sudo
  nano<i style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'> filename)</i><o:p></o:p></span></p>
  </td>
  <td width=377 valign=top style='width:338.45pt;border-top:none;border-left:
  none;border-bottom:solid windowtext 1.0pt;border-right:solid windowtext 1.0pt;
  mso-border-top-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;mso-border-left-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;
  mso-border-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0cm;margin-bottom:.0001pt;line-height:
  normal'><span lang=EN-GB style='color:#92D050;mso-ansi-language:EN-GB'>Is
  stating a basic editor in the terminal to open or create a simple text or
  configuration file, mostly you have to add a </span><span lang=EN-US
  style='color:#92D050;mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>sudo</span><span lang=EN-GB
  style='color:#92D050;mso-ansi-language:EN-GB'> if you want to be able to
  write the files with root user rights. Closing the editor is done by ctrl+x
  and then choosing whether you want to save your changes or not<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr style='mso-yfti-irow:5'>
  <td width=188 valign=top style='width:154.25pt;border:solid windowtext 1.0pt;
  border-top:none;mso-border-top-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;mso-border-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;

<h2><a name="_Toc485150894"><span lang=EN-GB style='color:#92D050;mso-ansi-language:
EN-GB'>Initial configuration of Raspbian</span></a><span lang=EN-GB
style='color:#92D050;mso-ansi-language:EN-GB'><o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-GB style='color:#92D050;mso-ansi-language:
EN-GB'>The following steps make sure, that basic Raspbian configuration is
done. <o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span lang=EN-GB
style='color:#92D050;mso-ansi-language:EN-GB'>NOTE:</span></b><span lang=EN-GB
style='color:#92D050;mso-ansi-language:EN-GB'> There may be many tutorials in
how to set-up and configure Raspbian and going into more details about user
rights and other Raspbian features. This tutorial is showing the way which
worked for my project aiming to run openHAB2 on the Raspberry.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-GB style='color:#92D050;mso-ansi-language:
EN-GB'>Since this tutorial is using the PIXEL GUI I always refer to the PIXEL
way of configuring and only go back to the terminal way (text only) if it is
required.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-GB style='color:#92D050;mso-ansi-language:
EN-GB'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></p>

<h3><a name="_Toc485150895"><span lang=EN-GB style='color:#92D050;mso-ansi-language:
EN-GB'>Localisation:</span></a><span lang=EN-GB style='color:#92D050;
mso-ansi-language:EN-GB'><o:p></o:p></span></h3>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-GB style='color:#92D050;mso-ansi-language:
EN-GB'>The 1.st thing you want to do is changing the localisation settings to
make sure your keyboard layout and WiFi settings are matching.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span lang=EN-GB
style='color:#92D050;mso-ansi-language:EN-GB'>NOTE:</span></b><span lang=EN-GB
style='color:#92D050;mso-ansi-language:EN-GB'> Do not change the password
before you have changed the keyboard layout since you might put in a different
password than you expect (e.g. US qwerty vs. German qwertz results in Raspberrz
instead of Raspberry)<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<h1><a name="_Toc485150920"><span lang=EN-GB style='mso-ansi-language:EN-GB'>Chapter
6: Installation of openHAB2 on Raspberry</span></a><span lang=EN-GB
style='mso-ansi-language:EN-GB'><o:p></o:p></span></h1>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-GB style='mso-ansi-language:EN-GB'>This
tutorial is only focussing on the package repository installation of the stable
version and only on the add-ons for the listed hardware. All other
installations are described on the openhab.org site installation for Linux: (</span><a
href="http://docs.openhab.org/installation/linux.html#package-repository-installation"><span
class=berschrift9Zchn><span lang=EN-GB style='font-size:10.0pt;line-height:
115%;color:windowtext;mso-ansi-language:EN-GB;text-decoration:none;text-underline:
none'>http://docs.openhab.org/installation/linux.html#package-repository-installation</span></span></a><span
lang=EN-GB style='mso-ansi-language:EN-GB'>) For the Raspbian you have to go
for the Apt Based Systems part of it.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<table class=MsoTableGrid border=1 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0
 style='border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-layout-alt:fixed;border:none;
 mso-border-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;mso-yfti-tbllook:1184;mso-padding-alt:
 0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
 <tr style='mso-yfti-irow:0;mso-yfti-firstrow:yes'>

  <p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0cm;margin-bottom:.0001pt;line-height:
  normal'><span lang=EN-GB style='mso-ansi-language:EN-GB'>Open Terminal<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  </td>
  <td width=580 valign=top style='width:274.65pt;border:solid windowtext 1.0pt;
  border-left:none;mso-border-left-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;mso-border-alt:
  solid windowtext .5pt;padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0cm;margin-bottom:.0001pt;line-height:
  normal'><span style='mso-fareast-language:DE;mso-bidi-language:AR-SA;
  mso-no-proof:yes'><v:shape id="Picture_x0020_113" o:spid="_x0000_i1146"

  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr style='mso-yfti-irow:1'>
  <td width=202 valign=top style='width:218.05pt;border:solid windowtext 1.0pt;

  padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0cm;margin-bottom:.0001pt;line-height:
  normal'><span lang=EN-GB style='mso-ansi-language:EN-GB'>First, add the
  openHAB2 bintray repository key to your package manager and allow Apt to use
  the HTTPS Protocol<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  </td>
  <td width=580 valign=top style='width:274.65pt;border-top:none;border-left:
  none;border-bottom:solid windowtext 1.0pt;border-right:solid windowtext 1.0pt;
  mso-border-top-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;mso-border-left-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;
  mso-border-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0cm;margin-bottom:.0001pt;line-height:
  normal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>wget -qO -
  'https://bintray.com/user/downloadSubjectPublicKey?username=openhab' | sudo
  apt-key add -<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0cm;margin-bottom:.0001pt;line-height:
  normal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>sudo apt-get install
  apt-transport-https<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr style='mso-yfti-irow:2'>
  <td width=202 valign=top style='width:218.05pt;border:solid windowtext 1.0pt;
  border-top:none;mso-border-top-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;mso-border-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;
  padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0cm;margin-bottom:.0001pt;line-height:
  normal'><span lang=EN-GB style='mso-ansi-language:EN-GB'>I choose the stable
  Official (Stable) build<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0cm;margin-bottom:.0001pt;line-height:
  normal'><span lang=EN-GB style='mso-ansi-language:EN-GB'>The stable builds
  contain the latest official release with tested features.<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  </td>
  <td width=580 valign=top style='width:274.65pt;border-top:none;border-left:
  none;border-bottom:solid windowtext 1.0pt;border-right:solid windowtext 1.0pt;
  mso-border-top-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;mso-border-left-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;
  mso-border-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0cm;margin-bottom:.0001pt;line-height:
  normal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>echo 'deb
  https://dl.bintray.com/openhab/apt-repo2 stable main' | sudo tee
  /etc/apt/sources.list.d/openhab2.list<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr style='mso-yfti-irow:3'>
  <td width=202 valign=top style='width:218.05pt;border:solid windowtext 1.0pt;
  border-top:none;mso-border-top-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;mso-border-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;

 <tr style='mso-yfti-irow:6'>

  </v:shape></span><span lang=EN-GB style='mso-ansi-language:EN-GB'><o:p></o:p></span></p>
  </td>

  <p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0cm;margin-bottom:.0001pt;line-height:
  normal'><span lang=EN-GB style='mso-ansi-language:EN-GB'>(but here!)<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0cm;margin-bottom:.0001pt;line-height:
  normal'><span style='mso-fareast-language:DE;mso-bidi-language:AR-SA;
  mso-no-proof:yes'><v:shape id="Picture_x0020_28" o:spid="_x0000_i1143"

   mso-wrap-style:square'>
   <v:imagedata src="test-Dateien/image071.png" o:title=""/>
  </v:shape></span></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr style='mso-yfti-irow:7;mso-yfti-lastrow:yes'>
  <td width=202 valign=top style='width:218.05pt;border:solid windowtext 1.0pt;
  border-top:none;mso-border-top-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;mso-border-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;
  padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0cm;margin-bottom:.0001pt;line-height:
  normal'><span lang=EN-GB style='mso-ansi-language:EN-GB'>If everything went

  <td width=580 valign=top style='width:274.65pt;border-top:none;border-left:

<h2><a name="_Toc485150922"><span lang=EN-GB style='mso-ansi-language:EN-GB'>openHAB2

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-GB style='mso-ansi-language:EN-GB'>This is
required to grant the PC based Eclipse Smart Home Designer access to the
requested configuration folder on your Raspbian. <o:p></o:p></span></p>

<table class=MsoTableGrid border=1 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0
 style='border-collapse:collapse;border:none;mso-border-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;
 mso-yfti-tbllook:1184;mso-padding-alt:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
 <tr style='mso-yfti-irow:0;mso-yfti-firstrow:yes'>
  <td width=230 valign=top style='width:239.95pt;border:solid windowtext 1.0pt;
  mso-border-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0cm;margin-bottom:.0001pt;line-height:
  normal'><span lang=EN-GB style='mso-ansi-language:EN-GB'>The shares are
  configured to be not open for guests nor to the public. Lets activate the
  openhab user as a samba user<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  </td>
  <td width=336 valign=top style='width:252.75pt;border:solid windowtext 1.0pt;

  solid windowtext .5pt;padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0cm;margin-bottom:.0001pt;line-height:
  normal'>sudo smbpasswd -a openhab</p>

 </tr>
 <tr style='mso-yfti-irow:1'>
  <td width=230 valign=top style='width:239.95pt;border:solid windowtext 1.0pt;

  normal'><span lang=EN-GB style='mso-ansi-language:EN-GB'>Enter the password </span><i
  style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'>openhabpassword</i><span lang=EN-GB
  style='mso-ansi-language:EN-GB'><o:p></o:p></span></p>

  <td width=336 valign=top style='width:252.75pt;border-top:none;border-left:

  <p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0cm;margin-bottom:.0001pt;line-height:
  normal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>New SMB password:<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0cm;margin-bottom:.0001pt;line-height:
  normal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Retype new SMB
  password:<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0cm;margin-bottom:.0001pt;line-height:
  normal'>Added user openhab.</p>
  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr style='mso-yfti-irow:2'>
  <td width=230 valign=top style='width:239.95pt;border:solid windowtext 1.0pt;
  border-top:none;mso-border-top-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;mso-border-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;
  padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0cm;margin-bottom:.0001pt;line-height:
  normal'><span lang=EN-GB style='mso-ansi-language:EN-GB'>Be aware, that
  creating and later using a specific user will ensure that permissions are honoured.
  Make sure, the openhab user has ownership and/or write access to the openHAB2
  configuration files. This can be accomplished by executing:<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  </td>
  <td width=336 valign=top style='width:252.75pt;border-top:none;border-left:
  none;border-bottom:solid windowtext 1.0pt;border-right:solid windowtext 1.0pt;
  mso-border-top-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;mso-border-left-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;
  mso-border-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>

 <tr style='mso-yfti-irow:3'>

  <td width=336 valign=top style='width:252.75pt;border-top:none;border-left:
  none;border-bottom:solid windowtext 1.0pt;border-right:solid windowtext 1.0pt;
  mso-border-top-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;mso-border-left-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;

  normal'><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>sudo systemctl
  restart smbd.service<o:p></o:p></span></p>

 </tr>
 <tr style='mso-yfti-irow:4'>
  <td width=230 valign=top style='width:239.95pt;border:solid windowtext 1.0pt;
  border-top:none;mso-border-top-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;mso-border-alt:solid windowtext .5pt;
  padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt'>
  <p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0cm;margin-bottom:.0001pt;line-height:

  EN-GB'>) enter in the CMD Prompt (just put </span><span lang=EN-US
  style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>CMD</span><span lang=EN-GB style='mso-ansi-language:
  EN-GB'> in the search of Windows 10 to open the command prompt)<o:p></o:p></span></p>
  </td>
  <td width=336 valign=top style='width:252.75pt;border-top:none;border-left:
  none;border-bottom:solid windowtext 1.0pt;border-right:solid windowtext 1.0pt;

<h2><a name="_Toc485150923"><span lang=EN-GB style='mso-ansi-language:EN-GB'>openHAB2
Privileges for Common Peripherals&#59149;</span></a><span lang=EN-GB
style='mso-ansi-language:EN-GB'><o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-GB style='mso-ansi-language:EN-GB'>An openHAB2
setup will often rely on hardware like a modem, transceiver or adapter to
interface with home automation hardware. Examples are a Z-Wave, Enocean or
RXFcom USB Stick or a Raspberry Pi add-on board connected to the serial port on
its GPIOs. In order to allow openHAB2 to communicate with additional
peripherals, it has to be added to corresponding Linux groups. The following
example shows how to add Linux user openHAB2 to the often needed groups </span><span
lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>dialout</span><span lang=EN-GB
style='mso-ansi-language:EN-GB'> and </span><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:
EN-US'>tty</span><span lang=EN-GB style='mso-ansi-language:EN-GB'>. Additional
groups may be needed, depending on your hardware and software setup.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<h1><a name="_Toc485150931"><span lang=EN-GB style='mso-ansi-language:EN-GB'>openHAB
(no 2) vs. openHAB2</span></a><span lang=EN-GB style='mso-ansi-language:EN-GB'><o:p></o:p></span></h1>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-GB style='mso-ansi-language:EN-GB'>One of the
most important things I had to learn is that there is also an openHAB (no 2)!
So here are a few things if found out to be considerable if you are using
openHAB2:<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt;mso-list:l7 level1 lfo9'><![if !supportLists]><span
lang=EN-GB style='mso-ascii-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;
mso-hansi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-ansi-language:
EN-GB'><span style='mso-list:Ignore'>-<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><span lang=EN-GB style='mso-ansi-language:EN-GB'>Always
make sure, that you are looking at the right version of openHAB when it comes
down to documentation, since a lot of older online documentation is refereeing
to the openHAB (no 2). When a few things might be done the same/similar way in
openHAB2, other things have changed and will not work in openHAB2<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt;mso-list:l7 level1 lfo9'><![if !supportLists]><span
lang=EN-GB style='mso-ascii-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;
mso-hansi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-ansi-language:
EN-GB'><span style='mso-list:Ignore'>-<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><span lang=EN-GB style='mso-ansi-language:EN-GB'>You
will also encounter two different ways of storing configuration in openHAB.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:72.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt;mso-list:l7 level2 lfo9'><![if !supportLists]><span
lang=EN-GB style='font-family:"Courier New";mso-fareast-font-family:"Courier New";
mso-ansi-language:EN-GB'><span style='mso-list:Ignore'>o<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><span lang=EN-GB style='mso-ansi-language:EN-GB'>In
openHAB (no 2).configuration was stored in files only<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:72.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt;mso-list:l7 level2 lfo9'><![if !supportLists]><span
lang=EN-GB style='font-family:"Courier New";mso-fareast-font-family:"Courier New";
mso-ansi-language:EN-GB'><span style='mso-list:Ignore'>o<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><span lang=EN-GB style='mso-ansi-language:EN-GB'>In
openHAB2 you can still use the files, but also can use database storage for
certain typs when you do the configuration with PAPER UI. This now might lead
to some confusion since you will not be able to change e.g. items in PAPER UI
which were configured using a text file. Also you would not have the correct syntax
highlighting in the Eclipse Smart Home Designer is expecting file configuration
only an items configured in PAPER UI will show up as errors.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:72.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt;mso-list:l7 level2 lfo9'><![if !supportLists]><span
lang=EN-GB style='font-family:"Courier New";mso-fareast-font-family:"Courier New";
mso-ansi-language:EN-GB'><span style='mso-list:Ignore'>o<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><span lang=EN-GB style='mso-ansi-language:EN-GB'>But
be aware that some configuration in openHAB2 still has to be done via text file
like e.g. rules. You might find already some progress in the snapshot release
of openHAB2, but I decided to base this tutorial on the stable release with
limited functionality in PAPER UI database<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt;mso-list:l7 level1 lfo9'><![if !supportLists]><span
lang=EN-GB style='mso-ascii-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;
mso-hansi-font-family:Calibri;mso-bidi-font-family:Calibri;mso-ansi-language:
EN-GB'><span style='mso-list:Ignore'>-<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span></span><![endif]><span lang=EN-GB style='mso-ansi-language:EN-GB'>Regularly
check the website of openHAB2 for news since a lot of new features are expected
to be implemented.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt;mso-list:l7 level1 lfo9'><![if !supportLists]><span

<h2><a name="_Toc485150945"><span lang=EN-GB style='mso-ansi-language:EN-GB'>Creating
items form things</span></a><span lang=EN-GB style='mso-ansi-language:EN-GB'><o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<h3><a name="_Toc485150946"><span lang=EN-GB style='mso-ansi-language:EN-GB'>The
concept of </span></a><span style='mso-bookmark:_Toc485150946'><span
lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Things, Channels, Items and Links</span></span><span
style='mso-bookmark:_Toc485150946'></span><span lang=EN-GB style='mso-ansi-language:
EN-GB'><o:p></o:p></span></h3>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-GB style='mso-ansi-language:EN-GB'>Before we
start please read first the concept of </span><span lang=EN-US
style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Things, Channels, Items and Links which is
directly tanken from the openHAB2 User Manual page </span><a
href="http://docs.openhab.org/concepts/index.html#things-channels-items-and-links"><span
class=berschrift9Zchn><span lang=EN-US style='font-size:10.0pt;line-height:
115%;color:windowtext;mso-ansi-language:EN-US;text-decoration:none;text-underline:
none'>http://docs.openhab.org/concepts/index.html#things-channels-items-and-links</span></span></a><span
lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'> <o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Things are
the entities that can be physically added to a system and which can potentially
provide many functionalities at once. It is important to note that things do
not have to be devices, but they can also represent a web service or any other
manageable source of information and functionality. Things provide their
functionality through a set of Channels. Channels are passive and can be
regarded as a declaration of a Thing, what it can offer. It is up to the
individual setup, which of the Channels are actively used through Items (see
below).<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Items
represent (fine-grained) functionality that is used by applications - as user
interfaces or automation logic. Items have a state and they can receive
commands.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>The glue
between Things and Items are Links. Links are associations between exactly one
Thing Channel and one Item. If a Channel is linked to an Item, it is enabled,
which means that the functionality that the Item represents is handled through
the given Channel. Channels can be linked to multiple Items and Items can be linked
to multiple Channels.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>To
illustrate these concepts, take a two-channel actuator that controls two
lights:<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-fareast-language:DE;mso-bidi-language:AR-SA;
mso-no-proof:yes'><v:shape id="Picture_x0020_98" o:spid="_x0000_i1087" type="#_x0000_t75"
 alt="http://docs.openhab.org/concepts/images/thing-devices-1.png" style='width:441.6pt;
 height:267.6pt;visibility:visible;mso-wrap-style:square'>
 <v:imagedata src="test-Dateien/image112.png" o:title="thing-devices-1"/>
</v:shape></span><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>The
actuator is the Thing. This might be installed in the electrical cabinet, it
has a physical address and needs to be setup and configured in order to be
used. The user is instead interested in the two lights, which are located at
different locations in his home. These lights are the desired functionality,
thus the Items and they are linked to the Channels of the actuator. A Link can
be regarded like a physical wire in this example.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<span lang=EN-US style='font-size:11.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Calibri",sans-serif;
mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";
mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-fareast;mso-hansi-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman";mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-bidi;
mso-ansi-language:EN-US;mso-fareast-language:ZH-CN;mso-bidi-language:HI'><br
clear=all style='mso-special-character:line-break;page-break-before:always'>
</span>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>The basic
process of in PAPER UI is explained on: </span><a
href="http://docs.openhab.org/tutorials/beginner/configuration.html"><span
class=berschrift9Zchn><span lang=EN-US style='font-size:10.0pt;line-height:
115%;color:windowtext;mso-ansi-language:EN-US;text-decoration:none;text-underline:
none'>http://docs.openhab.org/tutorials/beginner/configuration.html</span></span></a><span
lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'> <o:p></o:p></span></p>

<h1><a name="_Toc485150949"><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Chapter
11: Creating a dashboard for your home automation project</span></a><span
lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p></o:p></span></h1>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Every User
Interface on openHAB2 is providing its own style of dashboards to control your
home automation project, display current item states and attribute values or
even include online information like web pages.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>In our
configuration of openHAB2 you will have the choice of 4 different user
interfaces which can be selected <o:p></o:p></span></p>

<table class=MsoTableGrid border=1 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0
 style='border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-layout-alt:fixed;border:none;

  <p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:0cm;margin-bottom:.0001pt;line-height:

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>KeyFob_Gen5<o:p></o:p></span></p>

some items linked to<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Z-Wave Node

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>NOTE: When

the old color.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<h2><a name="_Toc485150961"><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Further
Rule examples based on this home automation project:</span></a><span
lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<h3><a name="_Toc485150962"><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>Switching
ON/OFF switches based on luminance reading of the multisensory</span></a><span
lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'><o:p></o:p></span></h3>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>The rule is
designed to switch on/off the Z-Wave Node 2: FGS223 Double Switch 2 based on
the illumination measured by the Z-Wave Node 6: ZW100 MultiSensor 6<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>The trigger
value is set to 10 LUX <o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>To prevent
von switching on/off if the illumination is around 10 lumen and e.g. just a
cloud is casting a temporarily shadow, there is a counter included which is
measuring multiple times the illumination and only allows to triggering the
switch if there reading is consistently (10 times) above or below the trigger
value.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>NOTE: Make
sure you have create the item Counter_Item since its used in the rule (see:
part Creating an item the see the value of a variable of a rule online in
this chapter). <o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>REMARK:
This was done as some kind of coding and configuring HABPANEL exercise. You
might get the same result in just checking the reading in a less frequent
period, forget about the counter and just trigger the switch when the
illumination reading is above or below the trigger value.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US'>You can
also use this Counter_Item to display some tendency whether your light is about
to switch ON/OFF depending on the value of the Counter_Item on your dashboard.
So if you play a little with the knob widget in HABPANEL it might look like
this:<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-fareast-language:DE;mso-bidi-language:AR-SA;
mso-no-proof:yes'><v:shape id="Picture_x0020_243" o:spid="_x0000_i1029" type="#_x0000_t75"
 style='width:86.4pt;height:85.2pt;visibility:visible;mso-wrap-style:square'>
 <v:imagedata src="test-Dateien/image161.png" o:title="" cropleft="46644f"/>
</v:shape></span><span style='mso-ansi-language:EN-US;mso-fareast-language:
DE;mso-bidi-language:AR-SA;mso-no-proof:yes'><span
style='mso-spacerun:yes'> </span></span><span style='mso-fareast-language:DE;
